channel.title: Nature - Issue - nature.com science feeds
channel.description: Nature is the international weekly journal of science: a magazine style journal that publishes full-length research papers in all disciplines of science, as well as News and Views, reviews, news, features, commentaries, web focuses and more, covering all branches of science and how science impacts upon all aspects of society and life.
channel.dc:rights: © 2019 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2019 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Daily briefing: UAE will be the first Arab nation on Mars
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 August 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02373-2

The United Arab Emirates will launch a Mars mission. Plus: a promising new HIV vaccine and a placental microbiome plot twist.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: UAE will be the first Arab nation on Mars
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: To lift a crow’s mood, give it a toolkit
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 August 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02345-6

Clever crows are more cheerful after wielding simple instruments.
item.dc:title: To lift a crow’s mood, give it a toolkit

item.title: Milky Way’s twisted spiral revealed in 3D
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 August 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02364-3

Map of ultra-bright stars called Cepheids shows galaxy’s warped disk.
item.dc:title: Milky Way’s twisted spiral revealed in 3D
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Working Scientist podcast: Global career moves, and how to survive them
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 August 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02365-2

Moving abroad is a fact of life for many scientists. Astrophysicist Elizabeth Tasker offers some advice.
item.dc:title: Working Scientist podcast: Global career moves, and how to survive them
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould

item.title: ‘Tropical Trump’ sparks unprecedented crisis for Brazilian science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 August 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02353-6

Tensions are rising as Jair Bolsonaro’s administration questions the work of government scientists and institutes debilitating cuts to research funding.
item.dc:title: ‘Tropical Trump’ sparks unprecedented crisis for Brazilian science
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Publisher Correction: Absence of NKG2D ligands defines leukaemia stem cells and mediates their immune evasion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 August 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1475-x

Publisher Correction: Absence of NKG2D ligands defines leukaemia stem cells and mediates their immune evasion
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Absence of NKG2D ligands defines leukaemia stem cells and mediates their immune evasion

item.title: Weak average liquid-cloud-water response to anthropogenic aerosols
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1423-9

Satellite data for cloud tracks downwind of major pollution sources show a relatively small global average decrease in cloud water caused by anthropogenic aerosols, invalidating claims that aerosol-induced effects contribute substantially to climate cooling.
item.dc:title: Weak average liquid-cloud-water response to anthropogenic aerosols
item.dc:creator: Velle Toll
Matthew Christensen
Johannes Quaas
Nicolas Bellouin

item.title: Spectroscopic signatures of many-body correlations in magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1422-x

Scanning tunnelling spectroscopy and extended-Hubbard-model cluster calculations reveal that magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene is a strongly correlated electron system, similar to other unconventional superconductors.
item.dc:title: Spectroscopic signatures of many-body correlations in magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene
item.dc:creator: Yonglong Xie
Biao Lian
Berthold Jäck
Xiaomeng Liu
Cheng-Li Chiu
Kenji Watanabe
Takashi Taniguchi
B. Andrei Bernevig
Ali Yazdani

item.title: Publisher Correction: The metabolite BH4 controls T cell proliferation in autoimmunity and cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1459-x

Publisher Correction: The metabolite BH4 controls T cell proliferation in autoimmunity and cancer
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: The metabolite BH4 controls T cell proliferation in autoimmunity and cancer

item.title: Lysine harvesting is an antioxidant strategy and triggers underground polyamine metabolism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1442-6

The harvest of large quantities of lysine by yeast and other microbes triggers a reprogramming of redox metabolism, in which NADPH is channelled into glutathione metabolism to reduce levels of reactive oxygen species and increase tolerance to oxidative stress.
item.dc:title: Lysine harvesting is an antioxidant strategy and triggers underground polyamine metabolism
item.dc:creator: Viridiana Olin-Sandoval
Jason Shu Lim Yu
Leonor Miller-Fleming

Markus Ralser

item.title: ‘No one is immune’: Alaska’s scientists despair over plan to shrink state universities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02344-7

The University of Alaska’s governing board plans to consolidate campuses to cope with a 40% cut in state funding.
item.dc:title: ‘No one is immune’: Alaska’s scientists despair over plan to shrink state universities
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Lambert

item.title: Structure and mechanism of the cation–chloride cotransporter NKCC1
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1438-2

The cryo-EM structure of the zebrafish cation–chloride cotransporter NKCC1 reveals the domain organization, ion translocation pathway, ion-binding sites and key residues for binding activity, providing insights into the activity of this family of transporter proteins with key roles in physiology.
item.dc:title: Structure and mechanism of the cation–chloride cotransporter NKCC1
item.dc:creator: Thomas A. Chew
Benjamin J. Orlando
Jinru Zhang
Naomi R. Latorraca
Amy Wang
Scott A. Hollingsworth
Dong-Hua Chen
Ron O. Dror
Maofu Liao
Liang Feng

item.title: Daily briefing: Out of date before it’s published
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02351-8

How “living systematic reviews” can get on top of fast-moving fields, a plan to test a geoengineering project gains momentum and a revolutionary technique getting people with spinal-cord injuries back on their feet.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Out of date before it’s published
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Yeast cells handle stress by reprogramming their metabolism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02288-y

Stressed yeast cells take up the amino acid lysine and reprogram their metabolism to free up supplies of a stress-relieving molecule. Lysine uptake therefore increases the tolerance of yeast cells to stress.
item.dc:title: Yeast cells handle stress by reprogramming their metabolism
item.dc:creator: Jens Nielsen

item.title: Giant nonreciprocal second-harmonic generation from antiferromagnetic bilayer CrI<sub>3</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1445-3

Large second-harmonic generation is observed in antiferromagnetic bilayers of CrI3, providing information about the microscopic origin of layered antiferromagnetism and motivating the use of two-dimensional magnets in nonlinear optical devices.
item.dc:title: Giant nonreciprocal second-harmonic generation from antiferromagnetic bilayer CrI<sub>3</sub>
item.dc:creator: Zeyuan Sun
Yangfan Yi

item.title: Podcast: The placental microbiome, and advances in artificial intelligence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02347-4

Tune into the latest from the world of science, with Nick Howe and Noah Baker.
item.dc:title: Podcast: The placental microbiome, and advances in artificial intelligence

item.title: Environmental racism, the world as it isn’t, and a guided tour of the planets: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02302-3

Barbara Kiser reviews five of the week’s best science picks.
item.dc:title: Environmental racism, the world as it isn’t, and a guided tour of the planets: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Barbara Kiser

item.title: Memory editing from science fiction to clinical practice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1433-7

A Review of advances in memory-editing techniques in humans suggests that these techniques are advancing beyond science fiction and could hold promise for translation into clinical practice.
item.dc:title: Memory editing from science fiction to clinical practice
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Phelps
Stefan G. Hofmann

item.title: Exome sequencing of Finnish isolates enhances rare-variant association power
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1457-z

Exome-wide sequencing studies of populations in Finland identified 26 deleterious alleles associated with 64 quantitative traits that are clinically relevant to cardiovascular and metabolic diseases.
item.dc:title: Exome sequencing of Finnish isolates enhances rare-variant association power
item.dc:creator: Adam E. Locke
Karyn Meltz Steinberg

item.title: No bacteria found in healthy placentas
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02262-8

Analysis of hundreds of placentas provides convincing evidence that this organ does not harbour microorganisms that can enter the fetal gut — a key finding for research into how the human microbiota is established.
item.dc:title: No bacteria found in healthy placentas
item.dc:creator: Nicola Segata

item.title: Reply to: Do not discard Staphylococcus aureus WTA as a vaccine antigen
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1417-7

Reply to: Do not discard Staphylococcus aureus WTA as a vaccine antigen
item.dc:title: Reply to: Do not discard Staphylococcus aureus WTA as a vaccine antigen
item.dc:creator: David Gerlach
Yinglan Guo
Thilo Stehle
Andreas Peschel

item.title: Arctic wildfires, hybrid embryos and record-breaking heatwave
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02305-0

The week in science: 26 July–1 August 2019.
item.dc:title: Arctic wildfires, hybrid embryos and record-breaking heatwave

item.title: ‘Mosaic’ HIV vaccine to be tested in thousands of people across the world
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02319-8

The experimental vaccine targets more strains of the virus than any other ― and seems to have longer lasting effects.
item.dc:title: ‘Mosaic’ HIV vaccine to be tested in thousands of people across the world
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega

item.title: Genomic mechanisms for the evolution of flightlessness in steamer ducks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02234-y

The ability to fly has been lost in many groups of birds. A comparison of the wing structures and genomes of flighted and non-flighted species of steamer duck highlights a possible mechanism for the loss of flight.
item.dc:title: Genomic mechanisms for the evolution of flightlessness in steamer ducks
item.dc:creator: Julia A. Clarke

item.title: UAE Mars probe will be Arab world first
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02338-5

The United Arab Emirates will send the Hope probe to the red planet next year.
item.dc:title: UAE Mars probe will be Arab world first
item.dc:creator: Ehsan Masood

item.title: Towards artificial general intelligence with hybrid Tianjic chip architecture
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1424-8

The ‘Tianjic’ hybrid electronic chip combines neuroscience-oriented and computer-science-oriented approaches to artificial general intelligence, demonstrated by controlling an unmanned bicycle.
item.dc:title: Towards artificial general intelligence with hybrid Tianjic chip architecture
item.dc:creator: Jing Pei

item.title: Proxima junk
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02312-1

Welcome to the curiosity shop.
item.dc:title: Proxima junk
item.dc:creator: Mark Vandersluis

item.title: Maximized electron interactions at the magic angle in twisted bilayer graphene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1431-9

Scanning tunnelling spectroscopy is used to map the atomic-scale electronic structure of magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene, finding multiple signatures of electron correlations and thus providing insight into the sought-after mechanism behind superconductivity in graphene.
item.dc:title: Maximized electron interactions at the magic angle in twisted bilayer graphene
item.dc:creator: Alexander Kerelsky
Leo J. McGilly

item.title: Loss of p53 triggers WNT-dependent systemic inflammation to drive breast cancer metastasis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1450-6

Loss of p53 in mouse models of breast cancer leads to activation of WNT signalling, which promotes metastatic spread by inducing systemic neutrophilic inflammation.
item.dc:title: Loss of p53 triggers WNT-dependent systemic inflammation to drive breast cancer metastasis
item.dc:creator: Max D. Wellenstein
Seth B. Coffelt
Danique E. M. Duits

Karin E. de Visser

item.title: How plants perceive salt
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02289-x

High salt levels in the soil harm plant growth and limit crop yields. A salt-binding membrane lipid has been identified as being essential for salt perception and for triggering calcium signals that lead to salt tolerance.
item.dc:title: How plants perceive salt
item.dc:creator: Leonie Steinhorst
Jörg Kudla

item.title: ‘Chameleon’ crystals change colour under pressure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02324-x

Layered materials called perovskites give in to pressure by glowing red, orange and yellow.
item.dc:title: ‘Chameleon’ crystals change colour under pressure

item.title: Author Correction: Advanced maturation of human cardiac tissue grown from pluripotent stem cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1415-9

Author Correction: Advanced maturation of human cardiac tissue grown from pluripotent stem cells
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Advanced maturation of human cardiac tissue grown from pluripotent stem cells
item.dc:creator: Kacey Ronaldson-Bouchard
Stephen P. Ma
Keith Yeager

Kumi Morikawa

Masayuki Yazawa

item.title: Cholera toxin promotes pathogen acquisition of host-derived nutrients
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1453-3

Cholera toxin selectively promotes the growth of Vibrio cholerae through the acquisition of nutrients, including haem and fatty acids, from the host gut.
item.dc:title: Cholera toxin promotes pathogen acquisition of host-derived nutrients
item.dc:creator: Fabian Rivera-Chávez
John J. Mekalanos

item.title: Deep learning detects impending organ injury in the clinic
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02308-x

Organ damage is often detected late, when treatment options are limited. The use of artificial intelligence to continuously monitor a patient’s medical data can identify people at risk of imminent kidney injury.
item.dc:title: Deep learning detects impending organ injury in the clinic
item.dc:creator: Eric J. Topol

item.title: Charge-order and broken rotational symmetry in magic angle twisted bilayer graphene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1460-4

Charge-order and broken rotational symmetry in magic angle twisted bilayer graphene
item.dc:title: Charge-order and broken rotational symmetry in magic angle twisted bilayer graphene
item.dc:creator: Yuhang Jiang
Xinyuan Lai
Kenji Watanabe
Takashi Taniguchi
Kristjan Haule
Jinhai Mao
Eva Y. Andrei

item.title: Dietary methionine influences therapy in mouse cancer models and alters human metabolism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1437-3

In two patient-derived xenograft models of colorectal cancer and a mouse model of autochthonous soft-tissue sarcoma, dietary restriction of methionine influences the outcome of cancer and interacts with antimetabolite and radiation therapies, through effects on one-carbon metabolism.
item.dc:title: Dietary methionine influences therapy in mouse cancer models and alters human metabolism
item.dc:creator: Xia Gao
Sydney M. Sanderson
Ziwei Dai
Michael A. Reid

Jason W. Locasale

item.title: CD24 signalling through macrophage Siglec-10 is a target for cancer immunotherapy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1456-0

CD24 interacts with the tumour-associated-macrophage receptor Siglec-10 to inhibit the macrophage-mediated clearance of cancer cells, revealing a new ‘don’t eat me’ signal as a potential target for cancer immunotherapy.
item.dc:title: CD24 signalling through macrophage Siglec-10 is a target for cancer immunotherapy
item.dc:creator: Amira A. Barkal
Rachel E. Brewer
Maxim Markovic
Mark Kowarsky

Irving L. Weissman

item.title: Weak sensitivity of cloud water to aerosols
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02287-z

Human activities produce tiny airborne particles called aerosols. The discovery that the average impact of these aerosols on the water content of low-level clouds is minimal will lead to more-reliable models of future climate.
item.dc:title: Weak sensitivity of cloud water to aerosols
item.dc:creator: Anna Possner

item.title: Time to discuss consent in digital-data studies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02322-z

Anonymized data sets are growing and it is becoming easier to identify individuals. Research-consent procedures must be updated to protect people from being targeted.
item.dc:title: Time to discuss consent in digital-data studies

item.title: Plant cell-surface GIPC sphingolipids sense salt to trigger Ca<sup>2+</sup> influx
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1449-z

The sphingolipid GIPC in the plant cell plasma membrane binds to sodium and triggers calcium influx, thereby triggering responses to excess salt such as efflux of sodium ions from cells.
item.dc:title: Plant cell-surface GIPC sphingolipids sense salt to trigger Ca<sup>2+</sup> influx
item.dc:creator: Zhonghao Jiang

item.title: Spectroscopy of graphene with a magic twist
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02285-1

When two graphene sheets are stacked so that there is a specific angle between them, fascinating properties reminiscent of high-temperature superconductors emerge. Spectroscopy now provides insights into this behaviour.
item.dc:title: Spectroscopy of graphene with a magic twist
item.dc:creator: Mathias S. Scheurer

item.title: Human placenta has no microbiome but can contain potential pathogens
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1451-5

The human placenta does not have a microbiota, suggesting that bacterial infection of the placenta is not a common cause of adverse pregnancy outcome, but group B Streptococcus is found in approximately 5% of placental samples.
item.dc:title: Human placenta has no microbiome but can contain potential pathogens
item.dc:creator: Marcus C. de Goffau
Susanne Lager
Ulla Sovio
Francesca Gaccioli
Emma Cook
Sharon J. Peacock
Julian Parkhill
D. Stephen Charnock-Jones
Gordon C. S. Smith

item.title: How a revolutionary technique got people with spinal-cord injuries back on their feet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02306-z

Electrical stimulation has promised huge gains for people with paralysis. Now comes the hard part — getting beyond those first steps.
item.dc:title: How a revolutionary technique got people with spinal-cord injuries back on their feet
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Willyard

item.title: A clinically applicable approach to continuous prediction of future acute kidney injury
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1390-1

A deep learning approach that predicts the risk of acute kidney injury may help to identify patients at risk of health deterioration within a time window that enables early treatment.
item.dc:title: A clinically applicable approach to continuous prediction of future acute kidney injury

item.title: Do not discard Staphylococcus aureus WTA as a vaccine antigen
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1416-8

Do not discard Staphylococcus aureus WTA as a vaccine antigen
item.dc:title: Do not discard Staphylococcus aureus WTA as a vaccine antigen

item.title: From the archive
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02309-w

How Nature reported plans to exploit Australia’s natural resources in 1919, and to develop computers as teaching aids in 1969.
item.dc:title: From the archive

item.title: Alarming surge in drug-resistant HIV uncovered
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02316-x

The drug-resistant form of the virus has been detected at unacceptable levels across Africa, Asia and the Americas.
item.dc:title: Alarming surge in drug-resistant HIV uncovered
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega

item.title: Look beyond the lab for collectors of reusable data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02328-7

Look beyond the lab for collectors of reusable data
item.dc:title: Look beyond the lab for collectors of reusable data
item.dc:creator: Kendrick Taylor

item.title: Three pitfalls to avoid in machine learning
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02307-y

As scientists from myriad fields rush to perform algorithmic analyses, Google’s Patrick Riley calls for clear standards in research and reporting.
item.dc:title: Three pitfalls to avoid in machine learning
item.dc:creator: Patrick Riley

item.title: Author Correction: Epigenetic stress responses induce muscle stem-cell ageing by Hoxa9 developmental signals

item.title: Julia: come for the syntax, stay for the speed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02310-3

Researchers often find themselves coding algorithms in one programming language, only to have to rewrite them in a faster one. An up-and-coming language could be the answer.

Nature, Published online: 29 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02330-z

item.title: Getting the measure of living biomaterials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02263-7

A goal of tissue engineers is to use 3D printers to assemble living filaments into tissues that then transform into more-mature forms through predictable shape changes. A study of single living filaments provides a basis for this approach.
item.dc:title: Getting the measure of living biomaterials
item.dc:creator: Zev Gartner
Alex Hughes

item.title: High performance from extraordinarily thick organic light-emitting diodes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 July 2019; doi:10.1038/s41586-019-1435-5

Extraordinarily thick organic light-emitting diodes can be fabricated using hybrid organic–inorganic perovskites as the transport layers, thus relaxing fabrication constraints without affecting their efficiency, voltage requirement or durability.
item.dc:title: High performance from extraordinarily thick organic light-emitting diodes

item.title: Daily briefing: Current global warming is unparalleled in 2,000 years
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2019; doi:10.1038/d41586-019-02320-1

For more than 98% of the globe, the warmest period in 2,000 years has been in the past century. Plus, how virtual-reality mazes are unlocking brain mysteries and why opponents to a telescope in Hawaii are not anti-science.

item.dc:creator: Flora Graham
